2_1JHumjFpXMTtSgm1ygdHqsvL9321Z87NDc.body:
Look at it this way. 

- Do you already have a computer?
- Is fiddling with a few things considered a pain?
- Do you want to have to buy a new computer?
- Are you willing to pay a lot of money for a small bit of convenience?

If you answered Yes to all four questions you can get a Mac if you want, otherwise I'd recommend Linux.

8_1GgNo3CmxPd7n2pMSF3uyqf1XHvgtTUqCe.body:
> [ivanq](#comment_33_1CvyxRucf7BbDvGtFe5LayTS2qX88VN7Er): The main part of Reddit is subreddits, am I right? So, if we make subreddits as ZeroTalk clones and then make a main site (like reddit.bit) which has references to subreddits, will it work?

Makes more sense to create a merge site and each "subreddit" is a hub that people can choose to download and subscribe to. That way no one person has control over the content, but people don't have to worry about maintaining an up to date clone of the actual reddit clone itself if they don't want to. That also means people can freely make their own reddit clone if they want to but have it connect to the same posts, and hence, the same content and communities.

This is how ZeroMe functions on the backend, and is why there are a bunch of ZeroMe clones, but they all can communicate with each other still.

> [ivanq](#comment_35_1CvyxRucf7BbDvGtFe5LayTS2qX88VN7Er): I am a ZeroNet developer as well, a contibutor, wrote some libraries, etc. My idea was just simplified. But then, why can't we use ZeroMe as Reddit?

ZeroMe doesn't make an emphasis on the voting aspect. You can only like a top-post, you can't up-vote or down-vote any of the comments. There's also no comment threading so you just get a really long list of comments with no clear indication of who someone is replying to beyond maybe a username mention. And in its current form ZeroMe makes no distinction between hubs, so you can't easily talk to specific groups of people.

Those are three of the main aspects I think people want out of a reddit clone at least.

> [styromaniac](#comment_112_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): https://steemit.com/steemit/@steemitblog/steemit-com-is-now-open-source

That'd be interesting if somebody could port that to ZeroNet.

> [xianc78](#comment_8_141zS75MupoDVjN4p7ivG9pXUXjAm9jLBQ): steemit requires you to give your phone number and also sells your data.

If it's open-source then someone can clone it without including those things.

> [armitage](#comment_4_15NXsHCCfQw8BUSxnsapUH212qTtg29iFU): You mean like zero talk?

ZeroTalk is more of a forum with like buttons, not a reddit clone.

2_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body: At this point trying to get Ajit Pai to change his mind is pointless. He doesn't care about consumers at all and wants to push his own agenda regardless of public desire. You'd have more success suing the FCC or getting him replaced than actually changing his goals.

> [theanswerer0](#comment_4_1F2ZbgkHvpknveTB6wFa5xNEQBb8yxQnCR): Net neutrality is about censorship and keeping the FCC relevant. Deregulation is good. [...]

Only if you also encourage the creation of more ISPs to foster competition. Many locations in the US are monopolized by single ISPs so there is no free market. A lot of areas and states even have laws that make it near impossible for new ISPs to get a foothold. If you don't like your ISP you can't move to a different one since they are the only option in town. Your only option would be to choose between having internet through them or having no internet at all. And please don't give the bs excuse that you could just use a wireless solution through Satellite or Cell, as both have caps and technical limitations that make them impractical if you do anything more than casually surf the net. We already had news recently of Verizon Wireless booting people off it's network because they were using too much data in a rural area that was expensive for them to service, so now what are those people going to use to access the internet?
More details on the rural Verizon Wireless customer terminations: https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/09/verizon-kicking-people-off-network-for-using-just-a-few-gigabytes-a-month/

5_1tdPArKBRcAcJxnKWHbAv6NuXP4rZmRSR.body:
> [obiwanzanobi](#comment_45_1LUy9iAxeWsj1DP5L8V17Yb2vo87FucjgD): 
>if by that you meana built in plugin for each zeronet app, can you make it searchable? That would solve the issue of a >decentralized search engine I mentioned earlier in another topic.

He means a plugin for ZeroNet. It's included just disabled. Just rename the directory 
`.\ZeroNet\plugins\disabled-Zeroname-local` 
to 
`.\ZeroNet\plugins\Zeroname-local` 
in order to enable it. It taps into your local instance of Namecoin to work.
